docs.snippet: With a dozen Oscar nominations for "The King's Speech" and a lengthy profile in Vanity Fair, Harvey Weinstein is thought to be back. But Michael Moore is spoiling the party....
docs.lead_paragraph: He was a high-flying, sometimes-vilified character and he was hanging by a thread - no, we don't mean Spider-Man. We mean, of course, Harvey Weinstein, the other entertainment behemoth we love to puncture, and caricature. With a dozen Oscar nominations for "The King's Speech" and a few others scattered elsewhere, Mr. Weinstein is officially back, a turn of events proclaimed by our own David Carr, and solidified twice over, by a lengthy new profile in Vanity Fair, and by a lawsuit. As our colleague Michael Cieply reports, Michael Moore filed suit in Los Angeles against the Weinstein brothers, Harvey and Bob, over profits from "Fahrenheit 9/11," alleging "accounting tricks and financial deception" that defrauded him of at least $2.7 million in profits from his blockbuster 2004 documentary (or docbuster, as his acolyte Morgan Spurlock calls them).
docs.abstract: With a dozen Oscar nominations for "The King's Speech" and a lengthy profile in Vanity Fair, Harvey Weinstein is thought to be back. But Michael Moore is spoiling the party.

headline.main: A Lawsuit to Welcome Harvey Weinstein Back

docs.snippet: At the Oscar nominees' luncheon the two producers of this year's telecast urged the gathered to volunteer their mothers and mind the time limits....
docs.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES- The producers of this year's Oscar ceremony, Bruce Cohen and Don Mischer, had two topics to discuss at the nominees' luncheon on Monday: moms and lists.
docs.abstract: At the Oscar nominees' luncheon the two producers of this year's telecast urged the gathered to volunteer their mothers and mind the time limits.

headline.main: Oscar Producers Play Good Cop, Bad Cop

docs.snippet: One of the highlights of this year's Oscar nominees' luncheon was expected to be the Scott Rudin/Harvey Weinstein show. But things did not go exactly as planned....
docs.lead_paragraph: Beyond the quips at this year's installment of the Oscar nominees' luncheon, one of the highlights was expected to be the Scott Rudin/Harvey Weinstein show. These rivals, who have tangled in the past over cinematic awards bait, are both racing hard for best picture this season -- Mr. Rudin with "The Social Network" and "True Grit," and Mr. Weinstein with "The King's Speech." But as our colleague Brooks Barnes reports from the lunch at the Beverly Hilton, Mr. Weinstein got to work the room alone. Mr. Rudin was said to be home sick with pneumonia.
docs.abstract: One of the highlights of this year's Oscar nominees' luncheon was expected to be the Scott Rudin/Harvey Weinstein show. But things did not go exactly as planned.

headline.main: A Noticeable Absence at Oscars Luncheon

docs.snippet: With the Academy Awards coming up, an afternoon of lobbying over sushi and salad....
docs.lead_paragraph: With the Academy Awards coming up, an afternoon of lobbying over sushi and salad.

headline.seo: At Oscar Lunch, Bardem, Weinstein and More
headline.main: The Oscar Nominees, Lunching and Hoping
headline.print_headline: The Oscar Nominees, Lunching And Hoping

docs.snippet: At the largest nominee luncheon the Academy has ever held, there was a smattering of funny moments in the brief interviews the actors gave to the assembled press before the lunch....
docs.lead_paragraph: Did you watch? The Academy nominees' luncheon may still be live-streaming nearby, but we decided to take a break to update you on the proceedings. Once upon a time, the Bagger worked in politics, and the luncheon reminded us of the many, many glad-handing events where, before anything actually happened - if anything actually did - there was first a laundry list of acknowledgments for all the officials, bigwigs and F.O.B.s in the room. With 151 nominees present - the largest nominee luncheon ever - this was a laundry list of institutional proportions.
docs.abstract: At the largest nominee luncheon the Academy has ever held, there was a smattering of funny moments in the brief interviews the actors gave to the assembled press before the lunch.

docs.snippet: The Academy is opening up the red carpet and backstage experience at the Oscars with its "You're Invited" campaign. And on Monday, it is live streaming the Oscars lunch....
docs.lead_paragraph: This year's Super Bowl delivered great ratings, which is probably making the producers of the Oscars - the second-most-watched event in the U.S. after the ball game - extra antsy. This year the producers and the telecast's network, ABC, are aiming to increase viewership among younger people, with younger, weirder hosts (James Franco and Anne Hathaway), hipper singers (Florence of Florence and the Machine) and a promotional campaign aimed at breaking down the event's perceived fustiness. The campaign, called "You're Invited," opens up the red carpet and backstage experience to viewers at home via "ambitious live streaming" - a first, according to Ad Age.
docs.abstract: The Academy is opening up the red carpet and backstage experience at the Oscars with its "You're Invited" campaign. And on Monday, it is live streaming the Oscars lunch.

docs.snippet: Melissa Leo, pushing for a best supporting actress victory for her role in "The Fighter," has decided to go the D.I.Y. route with her ad campaign....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bagger is an avowed fan of the D.I.Y. So, apparently, is Melissa Leo, who has invented her own personal ad campaign. In a few spots in Hollywood trade publications last week, there were glamorous photos of Ms. Leo - a best supporting actress front-runner for her role as the brassy and big-haired matriarch in "The Fighter" - under the single word "Consider."
docs.abstract: Melissa Leo, pushing for a best supporting actress victory for her role in "The Fighter," has decided to go the D.I.Y. route with her ad campaign.

docs.snippet: You know we're close to D-Day when "Saturday Night Live" does not one but two Oscar-related sketches. And the Queen of England is apparently amused by "The King's Speech."...
docs.lead_paragraph: You know we're close to D-Day when "Saturday Night Live" does not one but two Oscar-related sketches (or it might just be, you know, low on material). This weekend's show opened with the guest host, Dana Carvey, reprising his "Wayne's World" character with Mike Myers, riffing on this year's nominees. (Their best picture pick: "Winter's -" uh - "Bone.") And the "Weekend Update" segment included Paul Brittain's impression of the multi-tasking James Franco, who revealed that he's not just hosting the Oscars and a nominee. "I'm also working the coat check room and smelting all the awards in my foundry. I like having jobs!"
docs.abstract: You know we're close to D-Day when "Saturday Night Live" does not one but two Oscar-related sketches. And the Queen of England is apparently amused by "The King's Speech."

headline.main: Wayne and Garth's Most Excellent Oscar List

docs.snippet: The snow fortresses in "Inception" may be cool, but the kind of painstaking detail in "The King's Speech" is what the Academy loves....
docs.lead_paragraph: Everyone except the Pittsburgh Steelers had an awards-riffic weekend. While fans of the black and yellow, like the Bagger, were crying into their Iron City beer, in Hollywood and New York writers, animators and art directors were celebrating. The latter group presented its prizes on Saturday, and "The King's Speech," "Inception" and "Black Swan" won, for period, fantasy and contemporary film, respectively.
docs.abstract: The snow fortresses in "Inception" may be cool, but the kind of painstaking detail in "The King's Speech" is what the Academy loves.

headline.main: Art Directors Give Some Oscar Clues

docs.snippet: Mary Cleere Haran, a classic popular singer and writer much admired for her cabaret shows celebrating the American song book, died on Saturday in Deerfield Beach, Fla., two days after a cycling accident. She was 58 and was living in Florida, havin...
docs.lead_paragraph: Mary Cleere Haran, a classic popular singer and writer much admired for her cabaret shows celebrating the American song book, died on Saturday in Deerfield Beach, Fla., two days after a cycling accident. She was 58 and was living in Florida, having taken a break from a career that saw her perform in every major New York supper club. Ms. Haran was struck from the side by a car coming out of a driveway, according to a friend, Bridge McIntyre. She never regained consciousness.
